creator: johnk@nstc.nec.com.au
text:
As jmeter progresses the specifics of the .jmx file can change wrt fully 
qualified class names of classes supporting a Jmeter test plan element.

This has sometimes broken my test plans (on the various nightlies of 1.8 and 
1.8.1).

For example, here is a minor difference in .jmx file arising between my 23rd 
Aug 2002 and 30th Jan 2003 checkouts of JMeter direct from the CVS repository:

120c120
< <property 
name="TestElement.gui_class">org.apache.jmeter.protocol.http.config.gui.UrlConfi
gGui</property>
---
> <property 
name="TestElement.gui_class">org.apache.jmeter.protocol.http.config.gui.HttpDefa
ultsGui</property>
304c304
< <property 
name="TestElement.gui_class">org.apache.jmeter.protocol.http.config.gui.UrlConfi
gGui</property>
---
> <property 
name="TestElement.gui_class">org.apache.jmeter.protocol.http.config.gui.HttpDefa
ultsGui</property>
444c444
< <property 
name="TestElement.gui_class">org.apache.jmeter.protocol.http.config.gui.UrlConfi
gGui</property>
---
> <property 
name="TestElement.gui_class">org.apache.jmeter.protocol.http.config.gui.HttpDefa
ultsGui</property>

I think this occurred when the specifics of the protocol and port of the HTTP 
request config changed from being radio button driven to text field driven in 
the GUI.

The change resulted in my old test plans failing to run correctly and being 
unable to display correctly in the HTTP URL related GUI.

In the past between 1.7.3 and 1.8 similar but more severe problems occurred.

Perhaps this can be mitigated by an approach similar to Tomcat system level 
configuration, which puts module configuration into server.xml and the binding 
of module to implementation in modules.xml.

This in turn may be made simpler by re-use of appropriate jakarta commons 
components for consuming XML config files.

Thanks for your work on jmeter.

creator: sebb@apache.org
text: I think this has been solved with the upgrade.properties file.
